description: Rapid Action for Citizens with Earth Observation

links.title: Global temperature - ERA5
links.subtitle: Air temperature at 2m above
links.shortdescription: Surface air temperature data is crucial for assessing and forecasting health risks related to extreme heat (heatwaves) and cold. This information helps public health officials issue warnings, plan emergency responses, and study temperature-related illnesses such as heat stroke and cardiovascular issues.

links.title: Relative humidity - ERA5
links.subtitle: Global relative humidity
links.shortdescription: Relative humidity (RH), combined with temperature, determines how hot or cold air feels (the heat index).

links.title: Wind U Field
links.subtitle: Gridded ERA5 is the fifth generation ECMWF reanalysis for the global climate and weather for the past 4 to 7 decades. This parameter is the wind U field
links.shortdescription: The 10-meter (10m) u-component of wind velocity from the Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS) is a fundamental meteorological variable used to calculate wind speed and direction near the Earth's surface. It represents the zonal wind flow (eastward wind, with positive values indicating flow from west to east) and, when combined with the v-component (northward wind), provides comprehensive data essential for numerous societal applications, particularly those impacted by wind power, severe weather, and ocean conditions.

links.title: Wind V Field
links.subtitle: Gridded ERA5 is the fifth generation ECMWF reanalysis for the global climate and weather for the past 4 to 7 decades. This parameter is the wind V field
links.shortdescription: The 10-meter (10m) v-component of wind velocity from the Copernicus Climate Data Store (CDS) is a fundamental meteorological variable representing the meridional wind flow (northward wind, with positive values indicating flow from south to north). When combined with the u-component (eastward wind), it allows for a complete calculation of wind speed and direction near the Earth's surface, which is critical for a wide array of societal applications.

links.title: Activity at shopping centers
links.subtitle: Occupancy of customer parking
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how busy customer parking areas were during different moments in 2020, using satellite images to detect either the number of parked cars or how much of the parking area was occupied. It offers an easy way to understand how people’s movements and shopping habits changed during events like the COVID-19 pandemic, giving a simple snapshot of activity around commercial areas.

links.title: Border crossing vehicles time series
links.subtitle: Volume of highway occupancy from Sentinel-1 data
links.shortdescription: This indicator aims at showing the increase in traffic jam observed at the border crossings. It uses the intensity of the backscatter signal from Copernicus Sentinel-1 over the highway as a proxy for the high density of vehicles.

links.title: Truck detections motorways indicator
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many trucks were moving on Europe's primary roads, based on satellite images taken between 2020 and 2021. By detecting the distinctive signal that moving vehicles leave in Sentinel-2 imagery, it provides a large-scale view of road freight activity beyond the major motorways. This helps people understand how goods were transported during times of disruption, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, and offers insight into the resilience and functioning of everyday supply chains.

links.title: Truck detections primary roads indicator
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many trucks were moving on Europe's primary roads, based on satellite images taken between 2020 and 2021. By detecting the distinctive signal that moving vehicles leave in Sentinel-2 imagery, it provides a large-scale view of road freight activity beyond the major motorways. This helps people understand how goods were transported during times of disruption, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, and offers insight into the resilience and functioning of everyday supply chains.

links.title: Parked plane detections
links.subtitle: Parked planes detected on Sentinel-2 data
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks how many airplanes were parked at major European airports over time, using satellite images to compare 2020 with previous years. Because air travel is closely tied to tourism, jobs, and the wider economy, the number of grounded planes offers a picture of how strongly the COVID-19 pandemic disrupted international mobility.

links.title: Flying planes detections
links.subtitle: Flying planes detected on Sentinel-2 data
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks how many airplanes were actually flying near Europe’s busiest airports by detecting them directly in Sentinel-2 satellite images. It shows how the air traffic rose or fell during the COVID-19 pandemic compared to normal years. Because air travel is closely linked to tourism, business activity, and the wider economy, these trends offer an accessible view of the pandemic impact on mobility.

links.title: Vessel density
links.subtitle: Vessel density description
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many ships were present in European waters each month, based on signals that all large vessels send out to share their identity and position (AIS – automatic identification system). The maps reveal how busy the seas were for different types of vessels, like cargo ships, ferries, or fishing boats, helping us see how maritime activity changed over time, including during the COVID-19 pandemic. It offers a view of how shipping, travel, and fishing support Europe’s economy and daily life.

links.title: Vessel density time series
links.subtitle: Vessel Density based on Copernicus Sentinel-1
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many ships were present in major European ports by detecting them directly in radar images from the Copernicus Sentinel-1 satellite. By mapping vessel activity at a 1 km scale, it provides a clear picture of how busy ports were each month. This helps us understand how maritime traffic evolved during events like the COVID-19 pandemic and how port activity reflects the movement of goods, travel, and economic recovery.

links.title: Vessel density for tanker
links.subtitle: Vessel density for tanker description
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many tanker ships were present in European waters each month, using AIS signals (location messages that all large ships send out, similar to a tracking system). By mapping where tanker ships travelled or stayed over time, it helps people understand how fuel, chemicals, and other essential liquid goods were moved across Europe from 2017 to 2021, including during the COVID-19 pandemic. It offers a view of how maritime transport supports everyday life and how supply routes respond to major disruptions.

links.title: Vessel density for non tanker or cargo
links.subtitle: Vessel density for non tanker or cargo vessels
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many non-cargo and non-tanker ships (such as passenger ferries, fishing vessels, or recreational boats) were active in European waters each month. It uses AIS signals, which are location messages that all large ships send out (similar to a tracking system). By mapping where these vessels were over time from 2017 to 2021, it helps people understand how everyday maritime activities changed, including during the COVID-19 pandemic, and how they contribute to coastal life, tourism, and local economies.

links.title: Vessel density for cargo
links.subtitle: Vessel density for cargo description
links.shortdescription: “This indicator shows how many cargo ships were active in European waters each month, using signals that all large vessels send to broadcast their identity and location (AIS - automatic identification system). By mapping where cargo ships spent their time, it gives a clear view of how maritime transport evolved from 2017 to 2021, including during the COVID-19 pandemic. It helps illustrate how goods move across Europe and how resilient our supply chains are during periods of disruption.

links.title: Ships detected in Sentinel-2
links.subtitle: Ships detected in Sentinel-2 data
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many ships were present in the industrial areas of major European ports, based on satellite images from Copernicus Sentinel-2. A machine-learning model detects vessels within selected port zones, offering an easy way to see how industrial port activity changed over time.

links.title: Crude oil storage - ICEYE
links.subtitle: Crude Oil Storage Volume as observed by ICEYE
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how full crude oil storage tanks are by using high-resolution radar (SAR) images from the ICEYE satellite constellation. By measuring changes in the height of floating tank roofs, it reveals how oil storage levels evolved over time. During the COVID-19 pandemic, reduced travel and economic activity led to a sharp drop in oil demand and record-high storage levels, helping people understand how global disruptions affect energy markets and the wider economy.

links.title: Intermediate goods production
links.subtitle: Assessment of intermediate goods production sites (steel mills/other metal production, cement production, chemicals/plastics production).
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how active key industrial sites, such as steel, cement, and chemical plants are by analysing very high-resolution satellite images. Signs like the number of cars in employee parking areas, visible exhaust plumes, or heat from industrial processes help indicate whether production is running normally or reduced.

links.title: Steel inventory timeseries
links.subtitle: Steel inventory monitoring in open warehouses from SAR (Synthetic Aperture Radar) backscatter signals based on Sentinel-1 data
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks how much steel is stored at major production plants in Europe using radar satellite data from Sentinel-1. Steel is a key material for sectors like construction, cars, and infrastructure, so changes in inventory levels can signal shifts in industrial demand or supply. By showing how steel stocks rise or fall over time, this indicator helps people understand how economic activity responds to disruptions such as the COVID-19 pandemic.

links.title: Carbon Monoxide observed by Sentinel-5p TROPOMI
links.subtitle: Global 3-daily Carbon monoxide
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows the amount of carbon monoxide (CO) in the atmosphere, measured from space by the Sentinel-5P satellite. CO is a pollutant produced by traffic, industry, and fires, and high levels can affect air quality and health. By mapping CO worldwide, this indicator helps people see where pollution is coming from, such as cities, wildfire regions, or industrial areas, and how it changes over time. It offers a clear view of how human activities and natural events impact the air we breathe.

links.title: Methane monitoring
links.subtitle: Daily Methane Monitoring
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows methane (CH₄) concentrations in the atmosphere, measured from space by the Sentinel-5P satellite. Methane is a powerful greenhouse gas, and tracking where it comes from, such as agriculture, energy production, or natural sources, helps us understand its impact on climate. By mapping methane levels globally, this indicator gives a clear view of how human activities and natural processes contribute to warming, and how these patterns evolve over time.

links.title: Sulfur Dioxide observed by Sentinel-5p TROPOMI
links.subtitle: Global daily SO2
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows sulfur dioxide (SO₂) in the atmosphere, measured by the Sentinel-5P satellite. SO₂ comes from both human activities (like power plants and industry) and natural events such as volcanic eruptions. High levels can affect air quality, human health, and even climate. By mapping SO₂ at high resolution, this indicator helps people see pollution hotspots, track volcanic plumes that may impact aviation, and understand how emissions travel across regions.

links.title: Ocean colour plankton - Atlantic
links.subtitle: Ocean colour plankton description
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows maps of chlorophyll concentration in the Atlantic Ocean, using data from the Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). Chlorophyll reveals how much algae is present in the water: normal levels support marine life, while unusually high levels, often linked to pollution from rivers, sewage, or agriculture, can signal declining water quality and risks to biodiversity. By providing daily, gap-free maps, this indicator helps people see where marine ecosystems are under pressure and how human activities and natural processes affect the health of the sea.

links.title: Ocean colour plankton - Black Sea
links.subtitle: Ocean colour plankton description
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows maps of chlorophyll concentration in the Black Sea, using data from the Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). Chlorophyll reveals how much algae is present in the water: normal levels support marine life, while unusually high levels, often linked to pollution from rivers, sewage, or agriculture, can signal declining water quality and risks to biodiversity. By providing daily, gap-free maps, this indicator helps people see where marine ecosystems are under pressure and how human activities and natural processes affect the health of the sea.

links.title: Ocean colour plankton - Mediterranean
links.subtitle: Ocean colour plankton description
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows maps of chlorophyll concentration in the Mediterranean Sea, using data from the Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). Chlorophyll reveals how much algae is present in the water: normal levels support marine life, while unusually high levels, often linked to pollution from rivers, sewage, or agriculture, can signal declining water quality and risks to biodiversity. By providing daily, gap-free maps, this indicator helps people see where marine ecosystems are under pressure and how human activities and natural processes affect the health of the sea.

links.title: Chlorophyll-a concentration maps
links.subtitle: Chlorophyll-a concentration description
links.shortdescription: This indicator maps water quality across regions by showing chlorophyll-a levels, which reflect how much algae is present in the water. While algae occur naturally, unusually high concentrations can point to pollution from sewage, industry, or agricultural fertilisers entering rivers and coastal waters. By comparing weekly satellite observations with long-term average conditions, these maps help people quickly see where water quality is better or worse than usual. They offer a clear, visual way to understand how human activities and natural processes affect the health of lakes, rivers, and coastal seas.

links.title: Regional water quality time series
links.subtitle: Regional water quality time series
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks water quality over time by measuring chlorophyll-a, a substance linked to the amount of algae in the water. While algae are a natural part of aquatic ecosystems, unusually high levels can signal pollution from human activities such as sewage, industrial discharge, or fertilisers from agriculture, which can harm biodiversity and lead to poor water quality. By comparing current measurements with long-term averages, this indicator helps people see when waters are cleaner than usual and when they may be under stress. It offers a clear way to understand how both natural conditions and human activity influence the health of coastal and inland waters.

links.title: Total suspended matter maps
links.subtitle: Total suspended matter description
links.shortdescription: This indicator maps the amount of material suspended in the water, such as sediments, organic matter, and pollutants, using satellite observations. High levels of suspended matter can reduce water clarity, affect aquatic life, and signal pollution from rivers, coastal erosion, or human activities. By comparing current conditions with long-term averages, these maps help people see where water quality is being affected and how coastal and inland waters respond to natural forces and human activities.

links.title: Sea surface temperature time series
links.subtitle: Key ocean monitoring indicator
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how sea surface temperature has changed over time at specific locations, based on CMEMS satellite products. The time series helps people understand long-term warming trends, seasonal patterns, and sudden temperature anomalies. Tracking these changes over weeks and years provides details of how climate variability and climate change are affecting our seas.

links.title: Sea surface temperature maps
links.subtitle: Sea surface temperature description
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows maps of sea surface temperature across several European sites, using data from the Copernicus Marine Environment Monitoring Service (CMEMS). By comparing current temperatures with long-term averages, the maps help people see where the sea is warmer or cooler than usual. This is important because unusually warm waters can stress marine ecosystems, affect fisheries, and signal marine heatwaves linked to climate change.

links.title: Population density
links.subtitle: Population density 2020
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how people are distributed across the world, mapping population density as the number of people living in each square kilometre. It combines census data with official United Nations population estimates to provide a consistent picture for different years. These maps help people understand where populations are concentrated or sparse, which is essential for planning services, managing resources, assessing exposure to risks, and understanding how environmental and societal changes may affect different communities

links.title: NO2 level vs Number of Ships
links.subtitle: Port Activities, sources of pollution and NO2 levels
links.shortdescription: Measuring the effect of maritime traffic on air pollution

links.title: NO2 level vs Number of People
links.subtitle: Port Activities, sources of pollution and NO2 levels
links.shortdescription: Measuring the effect of population density on air pollution

links.title: NO2 level vs Number of Cars
links.subtitle: Port Activities, sources of pollution and NO2 levels
links.shortdescription: Measuring the effect of road traffic on air pollution

links.title: Automobile inventory level
links.subtitle: Inventory level in logisitc areas of production sites
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many finished vehicles are stored at car manufacturing sites by using radar satellite images from Copernicus Sentinel-1. By monitoring changes in inventory areas over time, it reveals whether production is keeping pace with demand or slowing down. This helps people understand how the automotive industry responded to disruptions such as the COVID-19 pandemic and how supply chains for everyday products like cars are affected.

links.title: Agricultural production - area
links.subtitle: Agricultural production in Europe
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how much of the white asparagus fields in Brandenburg were actively harvested in 2020 compared to 2019. By using satellite data to detect activity on the ground, it helps illustrate how shortages of seasonal workers during the COVID-19 pandemic may have affected this labour-intensive crop.

links.title: Agricultural production - productive area
links.subtitle: Agricultural production in Europe
links.shortdescription: This indicator uses satellite images to show how much greenhouse harvesting activity took place in 2020 compared to 2019. Because crops like white asparagus in Germany and red berries in Spain depend heavily on seasonal workers, this helps illustrate how disruptions such as the COVID-19 pandemic can affect food production. It gives people a clear view of how labour shortages can influence farming activities and the availability of certain foods.

links.title: Agricultural workers
links.subtitle: Availability of agricultural workers
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how many people worked in tomato fields in the Apulia region of Italy, including both field preparation and harvesting. By combining satellite images with anonymised, aggregated mobile network data, it offers an overview of how many local, commuting, and foreign workers were active during the 2019–2020 seasons. This helps citizens understand how labour availability shapes essential food production and how external events, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, can affect the agricultural workforce behind everyday products such as tomatoes.

links.title: Fruit production
links.subtitle: Monitoring fruit production (Berries) in Huelva, Spain
links.shortdescription: This indicator counts the harvesting trucks seen near greenhouses in 2020 compared to 2019. Using high-resolution satellite images, it helps show whether fewer workers during the COVID-19 pandemic affected the harvesting of red berries in one of Spain’s main production areas. It offers an easy way to understand how labour shortages can influence how food is picked and brought to market.

links.title: Harvested parcels
links.subtitle: Evolution of harvested parcels in percentage
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how winter crops like wheat and barley grew and were harvested across Spain in 2020 and 2019, using frequent satellite observations. By tracking changes in crop health and harvest timing in each region, it gives citizens a clear view of how cereal production progresses each season.

links.title: Harvesting evolution winter cereal
links.subtitle: Monitoring row crop harvesting with satellite data
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows when key crops such as winter cereals were actually harvested compared to when they were expected to be ready. By using satellite data to spot delays, it helps us understand how events like the COVID-19 pandemic can affect farming activities and, ultimately, parts of the food supply chain. It offers a clear view of how resilient our agricultural systems are when unexpected disruptions occur.

links.title: Harvesting evolution winter rapeseed
links.subtitle: Monitoring row crop harvesting with satellite data
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows when key crops such as winter rapeseed were actually harvested compared to when they were expected to be ready. By using satellite data to spot delays, it helps us understand how events like the COVID-19 pandemic can affect farming activities and, ultimately, parts of the food supply chain. It offers a clear view of how resilient our agricultural systems are when unexpected disruptions occur.

links.title: Air Quality (NO2 concentrations) map
links.subtitle: Nitrogen dioxide in Europe - daily average
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) changed over time in Europe, using data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). NO₂ mainly comes from road traffic, heating, and industrial activities, and high levels can irritate the lungs and worsen asthma and other respiratory conditions. Tracking NO₂ helps us understand how everyday activities like driving affect the air we breathe.

links.title: Air Quality (NO2 concentrations) at city level (model)
links.subtitle: Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) time series
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) changed over time in major European cities, using data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). NO₂ mainly comes from road traffic, heating, and industrial activities, and high levels can irritate the lungs and worsen asthma and other respiratory conditions. Tracking NO₂ helps us understand how everyday activities like driving affect the air we breathe.

links.title: Air Quality (O3 concentrations) at city level (model)
links.subtitle: Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) time series
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks ozone (O3) levels near the ground in major European cities, data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). Unlike ozone high in the atmosphere, ground-level ozone forms on sunny days from reactions between pollutants from traffic and industry. High ozone levels can cause breathing difficulties and reduce lung function, especially during heatwaves. Monitoring ozone helps explain why air quality can worsen even when traffic is reduced.

links.title: Air Quality (O3 concentrations) map
links.subtitle: Ozone at global level - daily average
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks ozone (O3) levels near the ground across Europe, data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). Unlike ozone high in the atmosphere, ground-level ozone forms on sunny days from reactions between pollutants from traffic and industry. High ozone levels can cause breathing difficulties and reduce lung function, especially during heatwaves. Monitoring ozone helps explain why air quality can worsen even when traffic is reduced.

links.title: Air Quality (PM10 concentrations) at city level (model)
links.subtitle: Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) time series
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows changes in PM10 levels in major European cities, using data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). PM10 are larger airborne particles from road dust, construction, agriculture, and natural sources like desert dust. These can irritate the airways and worsen breathing problems, especially for children and older people. Tracking PM10 helps us understand how both human activities and natural events affect air quality.

links.title: Air Quality (PM10 concentrations) map
links.subtitle: Particulate matter 10µm in Europe - daily average
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows changes in PM10 levels across Europe, using data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). PM10 are larger airborne particles from road dust, construction, agriculture, and natural sources like desert dust. These can irritate the airways and worsen breathing problems, especially for children and older people. Tracking PM10 helps us understand how both human activities and natural events affect air quality.

links.title: Air Quality (PM2.5 concentrations) map
links.subtitle: Particulate matter 2.5µm in Europe - daily average
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air over time, at European level, using data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). These tiny particles come from traffic, wood burning, industry, and long-range pollution, and they can penetrate deep into the lungs and bloodstream. Monitoring PM2.5 helps explain long-term health risks such as heart and lung disease linked to air pollution.

links.title: Air Quality (PM25 concentrations) at city level (model)
links.subtitle: Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS) time series
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks fine particulate matter (PM2.5) in the air over time, at city level, using data from the Copernicus Atmosphere Monitoring Service (CAMS). These tiny particles come from traffic, wood burning, industry, and long-range pollution, and they can penetrate deep into the lungs and bloodstream. Monitoring PM2.5 helps explain long-term health risks such as heart and lung disease linked to air pollution.

links.title: Air Quality (tropospheric NO2 concentrations)
links.subtitle: Daily Nitrogen Dioxide
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows global maps of nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) levels in the lower atmosphere, measured from space by the Copernicus Sentinel-5P satellite. NO₂ mainly comes from road traffic, power generation, and industrial activity, and high levels can harm air quality and health. By averaging satellite observations over several days, these maps help people see clear global patterns in air pollution and understand how changes in human activity—such as reduced traffic during the COVID-19 pandemic—affect the air we breathe.

links.title: Air Quality (tropospheric NO2 concentrations) at city level
links.subtitle: NO2 detected at cities based on Sentinel-5P data
links.shortdescription: “This indicator shows nitrogen dioxide (NO₂) levels over major cities, measured from space by the Sentinel-5P satellite. NO₂ is mainly produced by traffic, heating, and industrial activities, and high concentrations can affect air quality and health. By averaging satellite observations over several days, the maps make it easier to see how pollution levels in cities change over time and how reductions or increases in human activity influence the air people breathe.

links.title: Fishing boats in ports
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of boats in ports

links.title: Tug boats in ports
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of boats in ports

links.title: Cargo boats in ports
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of boats in ports
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how the number of cargo ships in ports changed between 2019 and 2020. Cargo vessels reflect the movement of goods and raw materials, so changes highlight how global trade and supply chains were affected by COVID-19 restrictions.

links.title: Tanker boats in ports
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of boats in ports

links.title: Passenger boats in ports
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of boats in ports

links.title: Pleasure craft in ports
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of boats in ports

links.title: Search and Rescue boats in ports
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of boats in ports

links.title: Commercial fluxes
links.subtitle: Changes in the number of trucks in ports

links.title: GHS-BUILT-S-R2023A
links.subtitle: GHS built-up surface dataset GHS-BUILT-S_GLOBE_R2023A

links.title: Crude Oil Storage Index
links.subtitle: Level of oil in tanks based on SAR and optical data
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks how full crude oil storage facilities are across major European regions by combining satellite images with ship-tracking data. By showing changes in oil storage over time, it helps us understand shifts in energy supply, trade activity, and market conditions, especially during periods of disruption such as the COVID-19 pandemic or other economical or social crises.

links.title: Crude Oil Storage Index Europe
links.subtitle: Level of oil in tanks based on SAR and optical data Europe
links.shortdescription: This aggregated indicator tracks how full crude oil storage facilities are across major European regions by combining satellite images with ship-tracking data. By showing changes in oil storage over time, it helps people understand shifts in energy supply, trade activity, and market conditions—especially during periods of disruption such as the COVID-19 pandemic or geopolitical tensions

links.title: People Mobility Reports
links.subtitle: People mobility data showing the impact of COVID-19 lockdown restrictions

links.title: Covid-19 Cases
links.shortdescription: This indicator tracks the evolution of the number of COVID-19 cases, supporting several layers of public awareness, health system preparedness, and broader societal functioning.

links.title: Covid-19 Vaccinations
links.shortdescription: This indicator shows how COVID-19 vaccination levels changed over time in each country. By tracking the number of vaccinations administered, it helps people understand how quickly populations were protected and how vaccination campaigns progressed across different regions.

links.title: Crop yield
links.subtitle: Yield forecast under "what-if" scenarios
links.shortdescription: Crop yield is typically a forecast or estimate of the quantity of an agricultural harvest. It is a critical metric that links climate, environment, and human activity, directly impacting global food security, the economy, and public welfare. The societal impacts of reliable crop yield indicators include Global Food Security, Market Stability and Economics, Climate Change Adaptation, Agricultural Policy and Planning, and Sustainable Resource Management. Indicators are often developed using a combination of ground based data and remote sensing data.
insituSources: Meteorological data from local Meteorological offices (AT)

links.title: Water demand
links.subtitle: Yield forecast under "what-if" scenarios
links.shortdescription: In agriculture, indocators of water need (often expressed as crop water requirements, irrigation demand, or evapotranspiration) provide essential data for optimizing water resource management, ensuring sustainable agriculture, and mitigating the impacts of droughts and climate change.
insituSources: Meteorological data from local Meteorological offices (AT)

links.title: HOUHPI Minesweeper Game
links.subtitle: Indicator 1: HOUHPI Game mode

links.title: Health-Oriented Urban Heat and Pollution Index and Auxiliary layers
Wildlife Biodiversity Minesweeper Game
links.subtitle: Indicator 2: Wildlife Diversity Game mode

links.title: Wildlife Biodiversity Indicator
links.subtitle: Identify areas of high biodiversity

links.title: Heat Risk Indicator and Auxiliary Layers
links.subtitle: Highest-risk areas, characterized by poor insulation or LST and a vulnerable population (elderly and economically disadvantaged)

links.title: Flood mapping
links.subtitle: Automated flood map
links.shortdescription: This indicator maps flooded areas using Copernicus Sentinel-1 satellite images to show where water has temporarily covered land and urban areas during flood events. By detecting floods both in open landscapes and in cities, it helps people understand the extent and evolution of flooding, distinguish floods from permanent water bodies, and see which areas are most affected. This information supports awareness of flood risks and highlights how satellite data can help monitor natural hazards that impact communities, infrastructure, and safety.

links.title: Water turbidity
links.shortdescription: Water discharge — the volume of water flowing through a channel, such as a river or stream, per unit of time — is a fundamental metric for managing the global water cycle, ensuring public safety, supporting water resource management - including for drinking water and agriculture - and various economic sectors, and maintaining ecosystem health.

links.title: Water Discharge Timeseries
links.subtitle: Variability of coastal and inland waters

title: RACE
